Two brothers, 16 and 23, have no home so they head west arriving in Spokane in time for the 1909 riots. Union organizers are denied the freedom to protest and speak publicly. Police brutality puts one brother in jail while the other goes with a union organizer to raise money. The novel is a real page turner and certainly timely. A Wild Winter Swan is a wonderful fairy tale about a fairy tale and a lonely girl growing up. There is probably a literary term for stories where things just keep going wrong, one after the next, where every story beat is yet another disaster that you may or may not have seen coming. I love fairy tale retellings, but this really felt like the fairy tale was added as an afterthought. The swan boy could have been a stray dog for all he added to the story. It was about an Italian family preparing for an important Christmas dinner party and a young girl struggling to cope with loss and deal with bullies at school. That part of the story was interesting but I don't understand why there were lengthy parts about meal prep while the swan part of the story was so limited.

The main point of this story seems to be Laura's growth out of childhood. Because of that, it was more of building up this childish atmosphere through wordplay and Laura's own thought, than any true plot. Laura herself felt vastly younger than the 15 years she was supposedly supposed to have lived.

This is a magical realism story but the same story could have been told without the magic which left me wondering why the boy with one wing was even there.

The pace was slow, the writing was dry and there were far more characters and storylines than I cared to keep up with. I gave up after about 50 pages. This is a well-crafted mystery written in the style of the Sam Spade detective novels. Taking place during World War II, it is the first in a series introducing strong female detectives in a New York City private investigation firm. Not only will the readers get a mystery with clues the careful reader will pull out form the story, but it also gives a feel for New York City life during the 1940‚Äôs.

Overall a quick read with an enjoyable writing style that did manage to hook my interest, but in the end I wasn't completely won over. The characters were a generally bit flat (but could've been so much more with their animated histories), and the plot just rolled out in a way that ended up not creating any nail biting twists (just more of an unsurprising, "Oh, okay, well I had assumed that person had something to do with it...")

Really charming - loved the dialogue/humor of the characters. A mysterious murder on Halloween, a fortune teller, NYC in the 40s, and a bad ass lady detective with a fun sidekick she got from the circus...it had a lot of fun classic murder mystery elements with some modern twists. A fun read and by the end I thought I would definitely read another story about this detective and her assistant. Loved the characters and thought it was a very entertaining/fun read.

I loved this new mystery. The characters of Will and Miss Pentecost were so refreshing with enough backstory to keep me wanting more. The mystery was plausible, but not obvious. The setting of 1940s New York made me hear the music of that time when I read. I certainly hope there are more in this series. The dialogue, the descriptions of the dress, all of it was wonderful.

When I started, I hoped this would actually be a mystery I didn't have solved from the beginning. I was left disappointed on that note.
However, the book didn't leave me hanging in many other areas. Great characters, good writing, and definitely a few chuckles here and there. It was good to see some female characters who could hold their own and would give Mike Hammer a run for his money.

Three stars feels a bit harsh, because Fortune Favors the Dead is a perfectly fine period mystery with a welcome queer touch. For me, however, it didn't have that extra zing that really makes for a good read. I would have liked more sentiment, a touch of humor, or a more complex whodunit.

It's good, though.

REALLY Great start to what I hope is many more books in this series! Very strong female characters and set in the 1940s. There are some Lesbian situations so if you are uncomfortable with that, this may not be the book for you. Love the "gritty" detective feel, like a good black and white movie! Highly recommend.

Typical Follett: lots of characters, quick moving story, really bad guy and a bunch of admirable though (usually) flawed ones.

Follett‚Äôs excellent research is apparent. I learned a lot about village life in the Dark Ages, and the various occupations of villagers. Women were next to nothing, even noblewomen, and they had no agency in their own lives. I also learned about the stranglehold the church had on these villages.Follett is weak in character development and dialogue- it often reads like a bad soap opera.

There are few storytellers that can write a book three times longer than the average novel, and still have the reader wish it were even longer, to savor the spell it engenders. The setting, 11th Century England, becomes so real one feels inside it. Follett's characters foster empathy, hope, disgust and enmity and the plot, while sometimes predictable, is at all times interesting and absorbing. The Evening and the Morning is a joy.

The Help, Kathryn Stockett

The Help is a 2009 novel by American author Kathryn Stockett.

The Help is set in the early 1960's in Jackson, Mississippi, and told primarily from the first-person perspectives of three women: Aibileen Clark, Minny Jackson, and Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan.

Aibileen is a maid who takes care of children and cleans. Her own 24-year-old son, Treelore, died from an accident on his job. In the story, she is tending the Leefolt household and caring for their toddler, Mae Mobley.

This is a book that delivers on several levels: it is an entertaining and engrossing novel with drama, humour and sadness, but it also causes us to reflect on deeply moral and racial issues. While racism has existed for a long time and continues to unfold, the story provides a snap-shot into a time that is fascinating and how historically it manifested itself into society in the US. Wolf Hall (2009) is a historical novel by English author Hilary Mantel. Wolf Hall is a sympathetic fictionalised biography documenting the rapid rise to power of Thomas Cromwell in the court of Henry VIII through to the death of Sir Thomas More. The novel won both the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award. In 2012, The Observer named it as one of "The 10 best historical novels".
